moves.1. Nf3: My favorite opening for all my games
moves.2... Bg4: He moves his bishop to threaten my knight
moves.4... Bb4: Moving his bishop to threaten my knight
moves.6. Bd2: Moving my bishop to protect my knight
moves.12. Bb5+: I put him in check; now he has technically lost his queen because he has to move to protect his king. He could always move the queen back to protect it, but he'll lose it anyway.
moves.13. Qxd4: I take his queen! Now he will probably take my bishop, but no biggie.
moves.13... cxb5: He takes my bishop, as expected.
moves.14. Qd1: I move my queen back because at this point, I don't know what to do next.
moves.15. Qe1: Moving my queen out of the way
moves.18. Qc3: Moving my queen out of danger
moves.19. Qd3: Moving my queen out of danger
moves.19... Rfd8: Moving his other rook into the fray
moves.20. Qe2: I still don't know what to do, but I figure that his next move will be to move his knight so his rook threatens my queen.
moves.21. Qe4: Moving my queen out of danger and threatening his knight
moves.21... Rd7d4: Threatening my queen and protecting his knight
moves.23. Qxa6: Taking his pawn. Now that I think about it, it would have been better to do Qc7 to protect my pawn; if he tried to take my pawn, I could do Qxd8#.
moves.24. Kg2: Moving my king out of check
moves.25. Kg3: Moving my king out of check
moves.29... Rd2d4: Moving his rook to threaten another check
moves.31. Rfd1: This was probably not the smartest move. Instead, I should have done Qe8#.
moves.31... Ne2+: He puts me in check again
moves.32. Rxd4: I take his rook (therefore getting out of check). He resigned after this move. I think eventually I would have figured out the Qe8# after a while.
